occurrences.line_text: And hauing soone his armes about him dight,
My knight hers soone, as seemes, to daunger droue
Earely, so soone as Titans beames forth brust
He soone allayd that Knights conceiu'd displeasure,
His weapons soone from him he threw away,
The morrow next, so soone as ioyous day
Compeld him soone the spoyle adowne to lay.
Whom soone as his three enemies did vew,
Whence soone vpstarting much he gan repine,
Who to them stepping did them soone diuide,
That soone as he returned backe againe,
So shall you soone repaire your present euill plight.
Her pleasing tongue, that soone she pacifyde
Therefore so soone as he was out of vew,
The Prince soone hearkned, and his life forgaue.
For th'one is dead, and th'other soone shall die,
Gathered him selfe together soone againe,
I will them soone acquite, and both of blame assoile.
And buckling soone him selfe, gan fiercely fly
Soone as they spide her, Lord what gladfull glee
Of few greene turfes an altar soone they fayned,
The knight full gladly soone agreed thereto,
With sight whereof soone cloyd, and long deluded
And plast on his, he did it soone displace,
But soone as he appeared to their vew,
But Calidore soone comming to her ayde,
Meaning so soone, as they conuenient may,
Thereto they soone agreed, and earnest tooke,
But he him fast pursuing, soone approched neare.
The earth shall sooner leaue her kindly skill
No sooner thought, then that the Carle as fast
No sooner sayd, but streight he after sent
Eft soones of him had perfect cognizance,
Doth soonest fall in disauentrous fight,
The strong through pleasure soonest falles, the weake through smart.
Who seekes with painfull toile, shall honour soonest find.
Who meanes no guile, be guiled soonest shall,
And safest seemes, him soonest doth amate,
The driest wood is soonest burnt to dust.
And sooth to say, why I left you so long,
And sooth, men say that he was not the sonne
But sooth he is the sonne of Gorlois,
And sooth, it ought your courage much inflame,
And sooth it seemes they say: for he may not
But sooth is said, and tride in each degree,
But sooth it was not sure for womanish shame,
And sooth oft seene, that proudest harts base loue hath blynded.
And sooth they say, that he was borne and bred
That shall I sooth (said he) to you declare.
For sooth he was descended of the hous
Ne soothlich is it easie for to read,
For soothly he was one of matchlesse might,
Were soothly so, and that th'vnrighteous ire
And soothly it was sayd by common fame,
And soothly sure she was full fayre of face,
And but God turne the same to good soothsay,
Shewes, visions, sooth-sayes, and prophesies;
In wittie riddles, and in wise soothsayes,
And full of subtile sophismes, which do play
As Arthegall, and Sophy now beene honored.
With a new Louer, whom through sorceree
Is one Duessa a false sorceresse,
To haue bene wroght by that false sorceresse.
Ne shall auaile the wicked sorcery
A sordid office for a mind so braue.
Now being naked, to their sordid eyes
His Lady sad to see his sore constraint,
The same so sore annoyed has the knight,
And him encombred sore, but could not hurt at all.
Did search, sore grieued in her gentle brest,
The Sarazin sore daunted with the buffe
Before her stands her knight, for whom she toyld so sore.
A grieuous gout tormented him full sore,
And souce so sore, that they the heauens affray:
Doth weepe full sore, and sheddeth tender teares:
With flashing thunderbolt ywounded sore:
And looking louely, and oft sighing sore,
By this sad Vna fraught with anguish sore,
Fled farre away, of that proud Paynim sore afrayd.
The sad earth wounded with so sore assay,
Stroke one of those deformed heads so sore,
With mortall steele him smot againe so sore,
Of pitty deare his hart was thrilled sore,
Indeede (quoth she) that should her trouble sore,
And prickt with anguish of his sinnes so sore,
And festring sore did rankle yet within,
His bodie in salt water smarting sore,
For pitty of his paine and anguish sore;
At their first presence grew agrieued sore,
Yet sore amoued with so puissant push,
The scorching flame sore swinged all his face,
Faint, wearie, sore, emboyled, grieued, brent
Those that with sicknesse were infected sore,
Vpon his crested scalpe so sore did smite,
The cruell wound enraged him so sore,
And therewith scourge the buxome aire so sore,
The griefe thereof him wondrous sore diseasd,
So sore him noyd, that forst him to retire
And downe he fell, with dread of shame sore terrifide.
Againe she stricken was with sore affright,
For neuer liuing man, I weene, so sore
His onely hart sore, and his onely foe,
To shew how sore bloudguiltinesse he hat'th;
She set her downe to weepe for sore constraint,
His double burden did him sore disease.
That her on either side do sore assay,
Whom sore he bett, and gor'd with many a wound,
And being downe the villein sore did beat,
And hundred knots that did him sore constraine:
Ranckled so sore, and festred inwardly,
Sore chauffed at my stay in such a cace,
Said Guyon, Squire, sore haue ye beene diseasd;
Of whom sore hurt, for his reuenge
Sore bruzed with the fall, he slow vprose,
Nathelesse so sore abuff to him it lent,
(Said he) that thee so sore displeased hath?
That he his foe has hurt, and wounded sore,
For to dilate at large, but vrged sore
The varlet at his plaint was grieu'd so sore,
Him when the old man saw, he wondred sore,
Does scorch not halfe so sore, nor damned ghoste
Did alwayes sore, beating his yron wings;
In senselesse dreame; which sight at first him sore aghast.
Woxe sore affraid, and standing still a space,
And on the hauberk stroke the Prince so sore,
What warre so cruell, or what siege so sore,
And him so sore smote with his yron mace,
And sore annoyed, groping in that griesly night.
He found himselfe dishonored so sore.
And sore beset on euery side around,
For neuer sore, but might a salue obtaine:
Salue to your sore, yet loue can higher stye,
Within my bleeding bowels, and so sore
Ne can my running sore find remedie,
And sore reproch, when so her father deare
Sith a sore euill, which this virgin bright
And with sharpe fits thy tender hart oppresseth sore.
And sighing sore, at length him thus bespake;
And the great Castle smite so sore with all,
For all too long I burne with enuy sore,
That the fast earth affronted them so sore,
Then sighing softly sore, and inly deepe,
Least they their finnes should bruze, and surbate sore
For sore he swat, and running through that same
That stroke the hardy Squire did sore displease,
Where the third brother him did sore assay,
For of that cruell wound he bled so sore,
And his foule sore reduced to faire plight:
So still his hart woxe sore, and health decayd:
Yet wist she nought thereof, but sore affright,
And seized euery sense with sorrow sore opprest.
But many there she found, which sore accused
That she repented sore, to haue him angered.
But Phoebe therewith sore was angered,
Whom when as Venus saw so sore displeased,
And for his dearest sake endured sore,
Sore trouble of an hainous enimy;
That his sad mother seeing his sore plight,
That vgly shape so sore her terrifide,
At that same last extremitie full sore,
From her in flight, he found, that did him sore apall.
Yet therewith sore enrag'd, with sterne regard
Him bet so sore, that life and sense did much dismay.
The virgin, whom he had abusde so sore:
Which her ador'd, may sore repent with me,
Iust cause of dread, that makes ye doubt so sore?
That Ladies safetie is sore to be drad:
To errant knights be commun: wondrous sore
Right sore I feare, least with vnworthy blames
How to auenge himselfe so sore abusd,
But Paridell sore brused with the blow,
With roring rage, and sore him selfe does throng,
With Britomart, so sore did him offend,
And did consume his gall with anguish sore,
Then sighing sore, It is not long (said he)
Saw all this goodly sport, and grieued sore,
And him assayling, sore his carkasse teare,
For whom so faire a Lady feeles so sore a wound.
The warlike Damzell was empassiond sore,
But in the Porch, that did them sore amate,
Did beat and bounse his head and brest full sore;
For many other Nymphes he sore did shreek,
So sore, and with foule outrages opprest:
Thereat her noble hart was stonisht sore;
Whose too long absence him had sore annoyd,
That many of them mou'd to eye her sore.
Which when he thought, it grieued him full sore,
Why do ye striue for Ladies loue so sore,
Who with the sudden stroke astonisht sore,
So mortall was their malice and so sore,
Whereat she sore affrayd, yet her besought
But sharpely him assayld, and sore bestedde,
But that he yet was sore of his late lucklesse fight.
Whose sharpe prouokement them incenst so sore,
With which so sore he Ferramont assaid,
Or went away sore wounded of his haplesse hand.
So sore he sowst him on the compast creast,
They haue him taken captiue, though it grieue him sore.
Sir Brianor, so sore, that none him life behote.
So sore, that tombling backe, he downe did slyde
Beheld, he woxe therewith displeased sore,
That all those stranger knights full sore agrieued,
From heaping stroakes, which thereon soused sore:
Yeeld such a sore, that doth her grieuance hide,
Deawed with siluer drops, through sweating sore;
He blest himselfe, as one sore terrifide,
Shew'd change of better cheare: so sore a breach
But her therewith full sore displeasd he found,
In feeble Ladies tyranning so sore;
Sighing and sobbing sore, as if the paine
With dreadfull strokes let driue at him so sore,
Yet held her wrathfull hand from vengeance sore,
Right sore agrieued at her sharpe reproofe,
With which the Squire in her defence her sore astound.
Them follow'd fast, and them reuiled sore,
And eke through heauie armes, which sore annoyd
So sore, that to his saddle bow thereby
And sigh full sore, to heare the miserie,
From all foure parts of heauen doe rage full sore,
And layd at them so sharpely and so sore,
Tormented sore, could not containe it still,
And many salues did to his sore applie,
Who sore against his will did him retaine,
Which seeing Marinell, was sore offended,
Was troubled sore, ne wist well what to weene,
That it was no old sore, which his new paine procured.
Which of the Nymphes his heart so sore did mieue.
And shewed her to him, then being sore bestad.
Of present dayes, which are corrupted sore,
Lamenting sore his sorowfull sad tyne,
The sight whereof the Lady sore adrad,
That all the warders it did sore amate,
And far aboue thy forces pitch to sore.
Whom with sore hauocke soone they ouerthrew,
But by the shoulder him so sore he bit,
From dreadfull mouth of death, which threatned sore
And him reuiled, and reproched sore
Heard to the end, she was right sore bestad,
With sight whereof she was dismayd right sore,
They doe thy sire, lamenting sore for thee;
And dealt her blowes vnmercifully sore:
Which spitefull words she sore engrieu'd to heare,
And also of her wound, which sore did paine,
She sought with ruth to salue his sad misfortunes sore.
That all vnweeting haue you wrong'd thus sore,
The dreadfull sight did them so sore affray,
The Briton Prince was sore empassionate,
And lewd Impietie, that her accused sore.
He that whylome in Spaine so sore was dred,
But now his cruelty so sore she drad,
And Belge selfe was therewith stonied sore,
And grieued sore, that through his fault she had
That all my former praise hath blemisht sore;
That bloudie scutchin being battered sore,
Beheld, they her rebuked and vpbrayded sore.
Of their arriuall: wherewith troubled sore,
Lookt vp with eyes full sad and hart full sore;
And with his burdenous blowes him sore did ouerlade.
And whiles he combred was therewith so sore,
That with the souse thereof full sore aghast,
Vppon an hard aduenture sore bestad,
He sore doth wound, and bite, and cruelly torment.
He fiercely him pursu'd, and pressed sore,
And left sore wounded: but when her he mist,
This knight, whom Tristram slew, had wounded sore
So sore her sides, so much her wounds did bleede:
Of his sore vengeaunce, or to make auoure
By reason that her knight was wounded sore.
Whom pitying to heare so sore complaine,
Whom when the Saluage saw so sore distrest,
Wherewith the Prince sore moued, there auoud,
Had giuen them, whose griefe through suffraunce sore increast.
Their hearts were sicke, their sides were sore, their feete were
Of their sore maladies:
Inflicts with dint of sword, so sore doth light,
Giue salues to euery sore, but counsell to the minde.
Made all of rusty yron, ranckling sore,
To goe about to salue such kynd of sore,
Aye me (sayd then Serena sighing sore)
Full on his beuer did him strike so sore,
And gainst the cold hard earth so sore him strake,
And griesly wounds that him appalled sore.
What cared she, who sighed for her sore,
To see her sore lament, and bite her tender lip.
The villaine, wroth for greeting him so sore,
Him still reuiling and afflicting sore,
Addeem'd me to endure this penaunce sore;
So sore him scourgeth, that the bloud downe followeth.
And groning sore from grieued hart entire,
With grace from her, whose loue his heart hath sore engrieued.
Tell, me what were they all, whose lacke thee grieues so sore.
Had left, now gan afresh to rancle sore,
A sodaine sickenesse, which her sore opprest,
Who sighing sore, as if her hart in twaine
There she beheld, that sore her grieu'd to see,
That sore her payn'd, by any to be drest,
Ah well away (sayd he then sighing sore)
And sore oppresse, ne any him doth spare:
And seeing there, that did him pittie sore,
Bequeath'd to him, forslacked had so sore;
And rageth sore in each degree and state;
Who seeming sorely chauffed at his band,
They did about their businesse sweat, and sorely toyld.
Beautie, and money, they that Bulwarke sorely rent.
Sorely thereat he was displeasd, and thought
Into his hart, which it did sorely gryde.
My softened heart so sorely doth constraine,
And with their axes both so sorely bet,
So much more sorely to the ground he fell,
So sorely he her strooke, that thence it glaunst
For of that Carle she sorely bruz'd had beene,
For whom he now so sorely was bestad;
But with his heeles so sorely he him strake,
Them sorely vext, and courst, and ouerran,
Annoy this noble Knight, and sorely him constraine.
He sorely punished with heauie payne;
There he that knight full sorely bleeding found
For fell despight, to be so sorely crost;
Whom he likewise right sorely did constraine,
The surging seas, when they do sorest rage,
Or thou, Sir Peridure, her sorie state,
Though sad and sorie for so heauy sight,
Leading his friend away, full sorie to his vew.
Where sorie Britomart had lost her late;
But that same dwarfe right sorie seem'd and sad,
Full inly sorie for the feruent zeale,
Whereof I sorie, yet my selfe did bend,
A sorie sight, as euer seene with eye;
As neither glad nor sorie for their sight;
Which sorie sight when Calidore did vew
Vnder the greenewoods side in sorie plight,
Tho backe returning to that sorie Dame,
To seeke some comfort in that sorie case.
That seem'd to be some sorie simple clowne,
The soring clouds into sad showres ymolt;
Soring through his wide Empire of the aire,
And in their tops the soring hauke did towre,
For earthly sight can nought but sorow breed,
Thou martyrest with sorow and with smart,
In stupid sorow, sith thy iuster merit
Lamenting sore his sorowfull sad tyne,
O how great sorrow my sad soule assaid.
For many yeares of sorrow can dispence:
With proud foes sight my sorrow to renew:
And read her sorrow in her count'nance sad;
Could not for sorrow follow him so fast;
And thrilling sorrow throwne his vtmost dart;
At last when feruent sorrow slaked was,
Some secret sorrow did her heart distraine:
The chearelesse man, whom sorrow did dismay,
Feare, sicknesse, age, losse, labour, sorrow, strife,
Great woe and sorrow did her soule assay,
Faire Ladie, through foule sorrow ill bedight,
She wilfully her sorrow did augment,
As if her hart with sorrow had transfixed beene.
To cloke her guile with sorrow and sad teene;
His cruell sport, in stead of sorrow dew;
Or die with you in sorrow, and partake your griefe.
Of all my sorrow, and of these sad teares,
He that his sorrow sought through wilfulnesse,
And dolefull sorrow heape with deadly harmes:
Lamenting Sorrow did in darknesse lye,
A song of bale and bitter sorrow sings,
That with great sorrow and sad agony,
That he might know, and ease her sorrow sad:
Great shame and sorrow of that fall he tooke;
Least that too farre ye haue your sorrow sought:
Sorrow is heaped in thy hollow chest,
Huge sea of sorrow, and tempestuous griefe,
Her former sorrow into suddein wrath,
To sorrow huge she turnd her former play,
And forth together went, with sorrow fraught.
For great compassion of their sorrow, bid
In stead thereof sad sorrow, and disdaine
Of sorrow and despaire without aleggeaunce?
But rather chose to dye for sorrow great,
And seized euery sense with sorrow sore opprest.
At last when sorrow he saw booted nought,
And doth himselfe with sorrow new sustaine,
That all the sorrow in the world is lesse,
And wreake your sorrow on your cruell foe,
And sow vaine sorrow in a fruitlesse eare,
Then is your sorrow, certes if not more;
More for great sorrow, that he could not pas,
With other signes of sorrow and impatient teene.
As if no sorrow she ne felt ne drad;
Lewd Losse of Time, and Sorrow seeming dead,
Yet leaue vnto his sorrow did not yeeld,
Great cause of sorrow certes Sir ye haue:
Midst sorrow shewing ioyous semblance for his sake.
And pensiue sorrow pind and wore away,
And singing all her sorrow to the note,
Hath me much sorrow and much trauell cost;
Certes her losse ought me to sorrow most,
That none might heare the sorrow of my hart,
But to her selfe her sorrow did bemone.
Would change her paine, and sorrow somewhat ease,
There he her found in sorrow and dismay,
Who thinkes from me his sorrow all doth rize.
Ne cease her sorrow and impatient stound,
Sorrow, and anguish, and impatient paine
And to the dore of death for sorrow drew,
With sorrow, she betooke her selfe to rest.
But sigh't and sorrow'd for her louer deare,
Thus when they all had sorrowed their fill,
The vndeserued woes and sorrowes, which ye shew.
For sorrowes past; their griefe is with them gone:
Gan her admire, and her sad sorrowes rew,
Can heart, so plung'd in sea of sorrowes deepe,
Whiles thus I heare you of your sorrowes treat.
For bloud can nought but sin, & wars but sorrowes yield.
That all these sorrowes suffer for my sake,
Heare then, ï¿½ man, the sorrowes that vneath
Full litle weenest thou, what sorrowes are
In stead thereof sad sighes, and sorrowes deepe
Short end of sorrowes they thereby did find;
Yet after all these sorrowes, and huge hills
For louers heauen must passe by sorrowes hell.
Loe where the villaine selfe, their sorrowes sourse,
His sorrowes cause to be of her despis'd.
Then after many teares and sorrowes spent,
Though vaine I see my sorrowes to vnfold,
After long sorrowes suffered whyleare,
And sorrowes feeling, yet with conscience
Of former daies mishap, his sorrowes wicked sourse.
Or loth to let her sorrowes be bewrayd.
Oftimes it haps, that sorrowes of the mynd
And wretched sorrowes, which haue often hapt?
And sorrowes heapt on her in greater throng;
And sad to see her sorrowfull constraint
She fell to ground for sorrowfull regret,
And stroue to maister sorrowfull assay,
Where at his feete, with sorrowfull demaine
They with them led, both sorrowfull and sad:
Repentance feeble, sorrowfull, and lame:
The cause of that his sorrowfull constraint;
Both in full sad and sorrowfull estate;
Full sad and sorrowfull was Britomart
She forth was brought in sorrowfull dismay,
Then forth he cald from sorrowfull dismay
Did wexe exceeding sorrowfull and sad,
Faire Pastorella, sorrowfull and sad,
Most sorrowfull, most sad, that euer sigh't,
By his faire patients side with sorrowfull regret.
Griefe all in sable sorrowfully clad,
Right sorrowfully mourning her bereaued cares.
When he thus ended had his sorrowing,
And Scudamore here dye with sorrowing.
And bring vs bale and bitter sorrowings,
In sort as he him schooled priuily:
So forth they marchen in this goodly sort,
In seemely sort their corses to engraue,
In sort as through the world I did proclame,
Therein three sisters dwelt of sundry sort,
Straunge sort of fight, three valiaunt knights to see
Therein the mery birds of euery sort
Of euery sort and nation vnder skye,
Whom ouertaking, she in merry sort
And loath'd the loose demeanure of that wanton sort.
Of appetite with meates of euery sort,
It ill beseemes a knight of gentle sort,
And euery sort is in a sundry bed
And all about grew euery sort of flowre,
And in all shamefull sort him selfe with her defile.
Were heap'd together with the vulgar sort,
Bred in assemblies of the vulgar sort,
In friendly sort, that lasted but a while;
What time she vsd to liue in wiuely sort;
But farre away from these, another sort
But her attending in full seemly sort,
Whiles through the world she walked in this sort,
In sort as they were formed aunciently;
And like a sort of Bees in clusters swarmed:
But like a sort of sheepe dispersed farre
In sort as ye haue heard the same of late.
To blot the same with blame, or wrest in wicked sort.
He chaunst to spy a sort of shepheard groomes,
This simple sort of life, that shepheards lead,
And set his rest amongst the rusticke sort,
To whome in sort, as he at first begonne,
It chaunst a sort of merchants, which were wount
Like as a sort of hungry dogs ymet
Prouided him a sword of meanest sort:
Infinite sorts of people did abide
In which ten thousand sorts of punishment
Great sorts of louers piteously complayning,
Both thirty sorts of fish, and thirty sundry streames.
And did in strength most sorts of men surpas,
(A sory sight) arraung'd in battell new,
Wroth was the Prince, and sory yet withall,
Restord, and sory wounds right well recured,
She inly sory was, and gan relent,
As seeming sory, that she euer came
Thither he brought the sory Florimell,
And all faire Ladies may for euer sory be.
The whiles her husband ranne with sory haste,
And he emongst the rest crept forth in sory plight.
During which space these sory eies haue seen
Which sory words her mightie hart did mate
Whereof she now more glad, then sory earst,
